wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the ContinuityBridge system overview. Explain its purpose as a middleware solution for transforming XML IFD payloads into canonical JSON format and routing them across enterprise logistics systems. Describe the high-level architecture including the frontend dashboard, backend processing pipeline, queue system, and integration capabilities. Highlight key benefits such as intelligent warehouse routing, fan-out dispatch, and support for multiple queue backends. Document the relationship between major components: client interface, REST/GraphQL APIs, transformation engine, decision logic, and external system integrations. Include real-world use cases in supply chain automation and integration scenarios with SAP, 3PLs, Amazon, and Mercado Libre. Provide architectural context for both technical and non-technical audiences, emphasizing scalability, reliability, and extensibility. Illustrate with a system context diagram showing data flow from ingestion to dispatch.

wiki_catalogs.name: XML to Canonical Transformation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the XML to Canonical transformation process in ContinuityBridge. Explain how the XMLToCanonicalTransformer class uses fast-xml-parser to parse incoming XML payloads and applies YAML-based mapping configurations to transform them into the standardized CanonicalItem format. Document the structure of the mapping.yml and order_release_to_canonical_order.yaml files, including support for XPath-like expressions, nested object mappings, type conversion, and optional fields. Provide concrete examples showing how a sample XML order payload is transformed into canonical JSON using the defined mappings. Detail error handling during parsing and transformation, including validation failures and missing required fields. Explain how the transformer integrates with the overall pipeline and passes data to subsequent stages. Include performance considerations for large XML documents and best practices for defining efficient mappings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Strategy Pattern Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the QueueProvider interface in ContinuityBridge. Explain how the strategy pattern enables runtime selection of queue backends (InMemory, RabbitMQ, Kafka) through a unified abstraction layer. Detail the QueueProvider interface methods including enqueue, consume, getDepth, and close, and their roles in message lifecycle management. Describe the QueueDelivery interface that provides explicit control over message acknowledgment, retry, and dead-lettering. Document the EnqueueOptions and QueueMessage interfaces that standardize message metadata across implementations. Illustrate with code examples how producers enqueue messages and consumers handle deliveries uniformly regardless of backend. Explain the type safety provided by TypeScript interfaces and how this enables seamless swapping of queue implementations. Include guidance on extending the system with new queue providers by implementing the QueueProvider contract.

wiki_catalogs.name: Pipeline Orchestration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for ContinuityBridge's pipeline orchestration system. Detail the Pipeline class implementation that coordinates the end-to-end processing flow from input ingestion to final dispatch. Explain the three input modes (flow, xml, canonical) and how the pipeline routes processing based on these modes. Document the step-by-step execution process: transformation via XMLToCanonicalTransformer, warehouse decisioning via OriginDecider, and fan-out dispatch through dispatchToReceivers. Describe the PipelineInput and PipelineResult interfaces that define the contract between the pipeline and its callers. Explain error handling and metrics collection mechanisms integrated within the pipeline. Illustrate how the pipeline integrates with the worker process and queue system to process messages asynchronously. Provide examples of each input mode in practice and document the traceId propagation for request tracking. Include sequence diagrams showing the control flow for each processing mode.

wiki_catalogs.name: REST API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive REST API documentation for ContinuityBridge's HTTP endpoints. Document all endpoints including POST /api/items/ifd (XML ingestion), GET /api/metrics (KPIs snapshot), GET /api/decisions (recent decisions), GET /api/events (event history), and worker control endpoints (/api/worker/toggle, /api/worker/concurrency). For each endpoint, specify HTTP method, URL pattern, request/response schemas, authentication requirements (JWT), and error codes. Include detailed examples using curl and JavaScript fetch API. Document the asynchronous processing pattern where XML is enqueued for worker processing and immediate response with traceId is returned. Explain the health check endpoint /api/health and its role in deployment monitoring. Provide usage examples showing how the dashboard interacts with these endpoints and how external systems can integrate via REST API.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dashboard Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the ContinuityBridge dashboard overview. Explain its purpose as the central monitoring interface for real-time system performance, including metrics visualization, event tracking, and worker status. Document the architecture of the dashboard using React, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS with ShadCN UI components. Detail how data is fetched via REST API endpoints like /api/metrics and /api/events/recent with automatic refetching every 5 seconds. Describe the layout structure with responsive grid organization and key visual elements such as MetricCard components displaying latency, throughput, and error rates. Include practical examples of interpreting performance trends and diagnosing system health. Address common issues like loading states and API connectivity problems, and provide troubleshooting guidance. Illustrate with annotated descriptions of the primary dashboard views and their data sources.

wiki_catalogs.name: Flow Concepts and Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the core concepts of flow orchestration in ContinuityBridge. Explain flows as configurable integration workflows composed of executable nodes connected via directed edges. Describe the flow lifecycle: definition, storage, execution, and monitoring. Detail the role of the FlowOrchestrator class in loading flow definitions, managing execution context, and traversing nodes in topological order. Illustrate with diagrams the data flow through a sample flow (e.g., BYDM-to-Amazon order fulfillment). Document the structure of FlowDefinition and FlowRun entities, including nodes, edges, and execution metadata. Explain trigger mechanisms (manual, scheduler, interface source) and how entry nodes are identified. Cover error propagation, execution tracing via traceId, and the distinction between emulation and production modes. Include practical examples from the codebase showing flow execution sequences and state management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Canonical Data Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the canonical schema used in ContinuityBridge. Detail the CanonicalItem interface defined in shared/schema.ts and its alignment with the JSON Schema definitions in schemas/canonical/. Explain the structure and purpose of each canonical model: order, inventory, shipment, and inbound. Document field definitions, data types, validation rules using Zod, and required/optional properties. Provide concrete examples from example schemas (SAP, WMS) to illustrate transformation use cases. Describe how these canonical models enable system interoperability and normalization across disparate source systems. Include usage patterns in transformation pipelines, mapping configurations (mapping.yml), and flow execution. Address common mapping challenges and provide best practices for extending or customizing the canonical models while maintaining compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: License Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for ContinuityBridge's license management system. Detail the RSA-based public/private key cryptography used for offline license validation, including key generation, license signing, and signature verification processes. Explain the structure of the LicenseData interface with fields like organizationId, licenseType, expiryDate, maxFlows, and features. Document the implementation of trial, annual, and perpetual license types with their respective constraints and feature sets. Describe the workflow for generating and validating licenses using the LicenseManager class, including error handling for expired or tampered licenses. Provide code examples showing how to programmatically create and validate licenses. Explain integration points with the export orchestrator and CLI tools. Address security considerations around private key protection and public key distribution. Include troubleshooting guidance for common license validation failures and best practices for license deployment in customer environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interface Templates
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the interface template system in ContinuityBridge. Explain how YAML-based templates in server/catalogs/interfaces/templates/ define connections to external systems such as SAP, 3PLs, Amazon SP-API, and Mercado Libre. Document the structure of interface templates including endpoint URLs, authentication methods, request/response formats, and error handling configurations. Provide examples from amazon-sp-api.yml, mercadolibre-api.yml, manhattan-wms.yml, and other template files. Detail how the InterfaceManager loads and validates templates at runtime. Include instructions for creating a new interface template, testing connectivity, and integrating it into a flow. Explain how templates are used by node executors like http_request.yml and interface_destination.yml. Address best practices for versioning, security, and performance optimization when defining external integrations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Render Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive deployment guide for ContinuityBridge on Render platform. Document the configuration in render.yaml including web service definition, environment variables, health check path, and auto-deploy settings. Explain the buildCommand and startCommand execution flow, including how npm run build triggers Vite build and esbuild for server compilation. Detail the postDeployCommand that executes scripts/render-postdeploy.js for post-deployment initialization. Cover environment variable configuration for production including DATABASE_URL, ENCRYPTION_KEY, and API keys. Explain the free plan limitations and port configuration (10000). Provide troubleshooting guidance for common Render deployment issues such as cold starts, environment variable synchronization, and health check failures. Include performance considerations for the free tier and recommendations for upgrading when handling production message volumes.

wiki_catalogs.name: XML Ingestion
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the XML ingestion endpoint POST /api/items/ifd. Detail the endpoint's purpose in receiving XML IFD payloads for processing in the ContinuityBridge middleware system. Explain the request format requiring a JSON body with 'xml' property containing the XML payload. Document the validation process using the Pipeline's validateXML method and the asynchronous processing pattern where valid XML is enqueued to 'items.inbound' queue with a generated traceId. Describe the immediate response structure containing traceId for tracking, enabling non-blocking processing. Include error handling for missing XML, validation failures, and server errors with appropriate HTTP status codes (400, 500). Provide practical examples using curl and JavaScript fetch API showing successful submission and error cases. Explain how this endpoint integrates with the worker process and how the traceId connects to subsequent processing stages, decision logging, and event tracking in the system. Document security considerations including authentication requirements and payload size limits.

wiki_catalogs.name: XML Processing Issues
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for XML processing issues in ContinuityBridge. Explain common XML parsing errors such as malformed XML, invalid encoding, and schema validation failures. Document how the XMLToCanonicalTransformer (server/src/transform/xml-to-canonical.ts) handles transformation and where failures typically occur. Detail the configuration options in xml_parser.yml and how they affect parsing behavior. Provide examples of problematic XML payloads and their solutions. Explain how to interpret error messages from fast-xml-parser and map them to specific configuration fixes. Include debugging steps for tracing XML transformation failures through the pipeline, from ingestion to canonical output. Address issues with XPath expressions in mapping configurations and type conversion errors. Provide guidance on using the dashboard's events page to inspect raw XML and transformation results.

wiki_catalogs.name: GraphQL Queries
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for ContinuityBridge's GraphQL queries including kpis, recentEvents, and decisions. Detail the kpis query that returns system performance metrics like average latency, P95 latency, transactions per second, queue depths, and error counts. Document the recentEvents query with its optional limit parameter (default 20) that returns processing events in reverse chronological order. Explain the decisions query that retrieves warehouse routing decisions with a default limit of 50 records in reverse chronological order. Provide examples of query syntax for each operation, including how to request specific fields and use parameters. Explain how these queries are resolved in the createResolvers function and their relationship to the REST API endpoints. Include examples showing how the dashboard consumes these queries for real-time monitoring and visualization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Order Canonical Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the canonical order schema used in ContinuityBridge. Detail the structure of the order.schema.json file and its alignment with the shared CanonicalItem interface. Explain each field including order identifiers, line items, customer information, shipping details, and status tracking. Document data types, validation rules using Zod, and required/optional properties. Provide concrete examples from example schemas (SAP, WMS) to illustrate transformation use cases. Describe how this canonical model enables normalization across disparate source systems like Amazon, Mercado Libre, and SAP. Include usage patterns in transformation pipelines, mapping configurations (mapping.yml), and flow execution. Address common mapping challenges such as order splitting, status mapping, and tax handling, and provide best practices for extending or customizing the model while maintaining compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: License Generation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the license generation process in ContinuityBridge. Explain the implementation of the LicenseManager class's license creation methods: createTrialLicense, createAnnualLicense, and createPerpetualLicense. Document the structure of the LicenseData interface including organizationId, licenseType, expiryDate, maxFlows, and features array. Provide code examples showing how each license type is generated with appropriate constraints (30-day trial with 5 flows, annual with 50 flows, perpetual with 100 flows). Detail the RSA-based signing process using generateLicense method that creates SHA256 signatures with the private key. Explain the role of the issuedAt timestamp in enforcing trial license duration independent of expiry date. Describe the key generation process via generateKeyPair method that creates 2048-bit RSA keys in PEM format. Include security best practices for private key protection and public key distribution. Address integration with the export orchestrator and CLI tools for automated license creation during deployment packaging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interface Template Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the structure of interface templates in ContinuityBridge. Explain each field in the YAML template schema including id, name, description, type, direction, protocol, endpoint, httpConfig, authType, requiredSecrets, endpoints, payloadTemplates, and suggestedMappings. Provide concrete examples from amazon-sp-api.yml, mercadolibre-api.yml, and manhattan-wms.yml to illustrate real-world configurations. Document how the Zod schema in template-catalog.ts validates template structure at load time. Include explanations of conditional logic schema and pricing metadata used in marketplace integrations. Detail how defaultFormat and formats fields determine payload handling. Explain the purpose of tags and metadata for UI filtering and organization. Address best practices for organizing template fields and maintaining backward compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mapping Syntax and Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the YAML-based mapping syntax used in ContinuityBridge. Explain the structure of mapping files including root-level properties like version, sourceFormat, targetFormat, and includes. Detail the mapping section with field-to-field configurations using JSONPath expressions (path), fallback fields, optional flags, and default values. Describe array handling via arrayPath and itemMapping for nested collections. Cover transformation functions (transform) such as toISO8601, parseInt, and parseFloat, and explain how they are defined in the transforms section. Include validation rules (required, type, format, min/max) that ensure data integrity post-mapping. Use order_release_to_canonical_order.yaml as the primary example, showing how each section contributes to the final canonical output. Provide syntax guidelines, common pitfalls, and best practices for readability and maintainability.

wiki_catalogs.name: InMemory Queue Issues
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for InMemory queue issues in ContinuityBridge. Explain the role of the InMemory queue as a fallback and development/testing backend. Document common problems such as message loss on process restart, lack of persistence, and unbounded memory growth under high load. Address race conditions in message acknowledgment and concurrency handling within the worker pool. Provide troubleshooting steps for diagnosing message disappearance, delayed processing, and incorrect queue depth reporting. Include guidance on monitoring memory usage and identifying leaks in the QueueProvider's in-memory implementation. Highlight configuration limitations and when to switch to a persistent backend. Use code examples from inmemory.ts to illustrate internal mechanics and failure modes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interface Source Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Interface Source Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeInterfaceSource handles the ingestion of data from external systems by leveraging interface configurations defined in the system. Document its interaction with the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage access, and detail how it retrieves and processes data based on the node configuration (e.g., interfaceId). Include examples from the code showing how input is passed through or enriched during execution. Describe its role as a trigger node in flow execution and how it integrates with poller nodes like SFTP or Azure Blob Poller. Address error handling behavior when interface configurations are invalid or data retrieval fails, and explain how metadata such as source system and timestamp is attached to the output. Provide guidance on debugging common issues like authentication failures or empty payloads.

wiki_catalogs.name: Status Mapping Tables
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the status mapping system in ContinuityBridge. Explain how status_map.yaml standardizes disparate status codes from various systems (BYDM, Amazon, MercadoLibre, etc.) into canonical values. Document the hierarchical structure with domain-specific sections (order, shipment, receiving, etc.) and demonstrate how status codes like '01'  'pending' or 'Shipped'  'shipped' are normalized. Show how the BYDM mapper uses the lookup field (e.g., status_map.order) to resolve status values during transformation. Include security constraints on file loading, error handling for missing tables, and examples from actual mapping files. Provide guidance on extending the table with new systems and troubleshooting common mapping issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Field Mapping Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for field-level mapping configurations in ContinuityBridge's YAML mapping files. Explain the structure of individual field mappings including the 'path' property using JSONPath-like syntax to extract values from source XML, the 'fallback' mechanism for alternative field sources, the 'optional' flag to control inclusion when values are missing, and the 'default' value assignment for null or undefined fields. Use examples from order_release_to_canonical_order.yaml such as orderId, externalOrderId, and customer.email to illustrate these concepts. Detail how the XMLToCanonicalTransformer processes these mappings during transformation, including the extractValue method's handling of optional fields and fallback chains. Include best practices for ensuring data completeness and reliability through strategic use of fallbacks and defaults.

wiki_catalogs.name: XML Parser Initialization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the XML parser initialization process in the XMLToCanonicalTransformer class. Explain how the fast-xml-parser library is configured with options like ignoreAttributes: false and attributeNamePrefix: '@_' to preserve XML attribute data during parsing. Describe the significance of these settings in the context of BYDM payloads which rely on attributes for metadata. Document the constructor's role in setting up the parser instance and loading the global mapping.yml configuration at startup. Include error handling during initialization and logging practices. Provide a code example showing how sample XML with attributes is transformed into a JavaScript object structure ready for mapping.

wiki_catalogs.name: Unit Testing Mappings
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive content for unit testing data mappings in ContinuityBridge. Explain how to use sample payloads such as orderRelease.sample.json to validate mapping accuracy and behavior under various conditions. Document the process of executing standalone mapping tests using the dev script with INPUT, MAP, and SCHEMA environment variables as shown in the README. Describe how to verify output structure against canonical JSON schemas (e.g., order.schema.json) using built-in validation rules. Provide step-by-step examples of setting up test cases for different message types (OrderRelease, Shipment, ReceivingAdvice, InventoryReport). Include instructions for running all POC mappings via 'npm run demo:mappingEngine' and interpreting results. Address best practices for creating additional test samples and expected outputs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Field Mapping Syntax
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the field mapping syntax used in ContinuityBridge's YAML configuration. Explain each directive including 'path' for JSONPath-based field extraction, 'fallback' for alternative value sources, 'default' for providing default values when source data is missing, 'transform' for applying reusable transformation functions, and 'lookup' for referencing external mapping tables like status_map.yaml and uom.yaml. Provide annotated examples from order_release_to_canonical_order.yaml showing how orderId, externalOrderId, and status fields are mapped using these directives. Document how optional fields are handled with the 'optional' flag and how nested objects like customer and shipTo are structured. Include guidance on best practices for writing reliable and maintainable field mappings, common pitfalls, and troubleshooting tips for mapping failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Field Mapping Processor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the field mapping processor focusing on the applyMapping function. Explain how it iterates through target fields and handles three distinct mapping types: simple fields, nested objects, and arrays. Detail the logic for determining mapping type using isNestedMapping and isArrayMapping checks. Describe how the function builds the result object incrementally, processes overrides, and respects optional field configurations. Provide examples showing how a flat field like 'orderId' is mapped versus a nested object like 'shippingAddress', illustrating the recursive application of mapping rules. Include error handling considerations when paths don't exist and best practices for structuring mapping definitions to avoid undefined values.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content detailing the full technology stack of ContinuityBridge. Break down frontend technologies (React, TypeScript, Vite, Tailwind CSS, ShadCN UI components), backend frameworks (Node.js, Express, Apollo Server for GraphQL), data processing libraries (fast-xml-parser, js-yaml), message queue implementations (amqplib for RabbitMQ, kafkajs), database layer (Drizzle ORM, Supabase), and validation tools (Zod). Explain the rationale behind each technology choice and how they integrate within the system. Document version compatibility, dependency management via npm, and build tooling. Include performance characteristics and trade-offs of selected technologies. Provide guidance on extending the stack with additional libraries while maintaining system integrity. Highlight how the stack supports the core functionality of XML transformation, pipeline processing, and real-time monitoring.

wiki_catalogs.name: Warehouse Origin Decisioning
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the warehouse origin decisioning system in ContinuityBridge. Explain how the OriginDecider class evaluates multiple warehouses based on proximity to destination, stock availability, SLA, and cost to determine the optimal fulfillment location. Document the scoring algorithm that uses weighted factors (stock: 50%, distance: 25%, SLA: 15%, cost: 10%) to calculate a composite score for each warehouse. Describe how the system handles cases with insufficient stock and selects the closest available warehouse. Provide examples showing how different order profiles (e.g., time-sensitive vs. cost-sensitive) affect warehouse selection. Explain the integration with the data pipeline, including how decision results are structured and passed to downstream dispatch systems. Include configuration options for warehouse data and strategies for maintaining up-to-date warehouse information. Address common issues such as coordinate inaccuracies and stock synchronization delays.

wiki_catalogs.name: InMemory Queue Backend
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the InMemoryQueue implementation in ContinuityBridge. Explain its role as a lightweight, zero-dependency queue system ideal for development and testing environments. Document the internal data structures used to manage message queues, concurrency control, and retry scheduling using JavaScript timers. Detail how it implements the QueueProvider interface methods including message persistence in memory, consumer registration with configurable concurrency, and depth tracking. Explain the message acknowledgment and retry mechanics, including how failed messages are requeued with delay via nextRetryAt timestamps. Describe the dead-letter queue simulation and how message ordering is maintained. Highlight limitations such as lack of persistence across restarts and single-process scope. Provide configuration guidance through environment variables and usage scenarios where this backend is appropriate. Include performance characteristics and memory considerations for high-volume testing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Transformation Engine
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the XML-to-Canonical JSON transformation engine. Explain how the XMLToCanonicalTransformer class parses incoming XML payloads and maps them to the standardized CanonicalItem format using YAML-based mapping configurations. Document the mapping file structure, including field-to-field mappings, value transformations, and conditional logic. Describe the validation process that checks XML structure before transformation. Provide examples of mapping rules from the order_release_to_canonical_order.yaml file, showing how complex XML hierarchies are flattened into canonical format. Explain how common mappings in the 'common' directory (like status_map.yaml) enable reuse across different transformation scenarios. Detail error handling for malformed XML or mapping failures. Include practical examples of input XML and corresponding output JSON to illustrate the transformation process. Address performance considerations for large XML payloads and memory usage patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: GraphQL API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive GraphQL API documentation for ContinuityBridge's GraphQL interface. Document the complete schema including queries (kpis, recentEvents, decisions) and mutations (processItemIFD, replayEvent, setWorker, setQueueBackend). Specify the endpoint at /graphql running on port 4000, authentication requirements (JWT), and query/mutation parameters. Provide detailed examples of GraphQL operations using both query syntax and curl commands. Explain the resolver implementation in resolvers.ts and how dependencies are injected into the resolver functions. Document the asynchronous nature of processItemIFD mutation and the replay capability through replayEvent mutation. Include examples showing how the dashboard could potentially use GraphQL for data fetching and how external systems can leverage GraphQL for integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation and Routing System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the navigation and routing system in ContinuityBridge. Thoroughly explain the implementation using React Router with route definitions for dashboard, events, queue, flows, ingest, and settings pages. Document the integration with SidebarProvider and AppSidebar components for consistent layout management. Detail how role-based access control affects routing, such as superadmin-only access to /admin/projects. Explain the routing logic in the App component's Switch statement and how SidebarTrigger enables responsive sidebar toggling. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing route-to-component mappings and conditional rendering based on user roles. Address common issues like 404 handling and authentication guards, and provide solutions for route accessibility and dynamic navigation. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding client-side routing patterns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Node Execution System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the node execution system in ContinuityBridge. Explain the executor registration pattern used in FlowOrchestrator, where each node type maps to a corresponding TypeScript executor function (e.g., executeXmlParser, executeObjectMapper). Document the NodeExecutor interface and ExecutionContext contract, including storage access, traceId, and emulation mode. Describe how the orchestrator dynamically dispatches node execution based on node.type using the executor map. Provide code examples from orchestrator.ts showing the executeNode recursive traversal and error handling. Explain the NodeExecutionResult structure containing output and routing metadata. Detail how executor metadata (like conditionMet) enables conditional routing in flows. Include guidance on debugging node execution through nodeExecutions logs in FlowRun. Address performance considerations around executor isolation and error containment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Schema Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the database schema architecture in ContinuityBridge. Analyze the Drizzle ORM definitions in server/schema.pg.ts and server/schema.ts to document all database tables including flows, mappings, events, decisions, interface configurations, users, and system metadata. Detail primary keys, foreign key relationships, indexes, and constraints. Explain the data persistence strategy for pipeline events, decisions, and audit logs. Document the integration with Supabase via config.toml and the role of Drizzle ORM in schema management and migrations. Include database schema diagrams showing table relationships and data flow. Provide guidance on querying patterns, performance optimization, and indexing strategies. Address data retention policies, backup mechanisms, and migration procedures for schema evolution.

wiki_catalogs.name: Phone-Home Validation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the LicensePhoneHome mechanism that provides optional online validation to prevent clock manipulation and license fraud. Explain how the system compares server time with client time to detect time-based attacks, using a 5-minute clock skew threshold. Document the HTTPS-based communication protocol between the runtime and validation server, including request payload structure (organizationId, licenseExpiry, signature, clientTime) and response handling. Describe the fallback behavior to offline validation when internet connectivity is unavailable. Provide implementation details of the static createValidationServer method that can be deployed as a serverless function on platforms like Render or Vercel. Include security considerations for deploying the validation server and protecting against replay attacks. Explain configuration options through environment variables like LICENSE_VALIDATION_URL and APP_DOMAIN. Provide troubleshooting guidance for timeout errors, invalid responses, and clock skew detection scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Mapping Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the YAML-based data mapping system in ContinuityBridge. Explain how mapping files transform source data (e.g., BYDM XML/JSON) into canonical JSON models defined in schemas/canonical/. Detail the syntax and capabilities of mapping rules including field-to-field mapping, value transformations, conditional logic, and lookup tables using common utilities like status_map.yaml and uom.yaml. Provide a step-by-step guide for creating a new mapping configuration, using order_release_to_canonical_order.yaml as a reference. Demonstrate how mappings are applied during pipeline execution via the ObjectMapper and xml-to-canonical transformer. Include practical examples showing input JSON/XML, mapping rules, and resulting canonical output. Address debugging techniques, error handling, and performance considerations when designing complex mappings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Migration and Initialization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for database migration and initialization process in ContinuityBridge. Explain the Drizzle ORM migration workflow triggered by 'npm run db:migrate' in the start script. Document the migrate.ts script that handles database schema synchronization and version management. Detail the init-database.ts script functionality for first-time setup, including seed data creation and initial configuration. Cover the Drizzle Kit configuration in drizzle.config.ts for schema pushing and migration generation. Provide step-by-step instructions for local development database setup using Supabase configuration in supabase/config.toml. Include guidance on managing migration scripts, handling schema conflicts, and rolling back failed migrations. Address production considerations such as migration safety checks, backup procedures before migrations, and zero-downtime deployment strategies. Document common issues like migration lock files, schema drift, and version compatibility between development and production environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Metrics and Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the metrics endpoints GET /api/metrics and GET /api/metrics/history. Explain how these endpoints provide real-time visibility into system performance and processing KPIs. Document the /api/metrics endpoint that returns a snapshot of current metrics including request counts, success/failure rates, latency statistics, and worker status by accessing the metricsCollector.getSnapshot() method. Describe the /api/metrics/history endpoint that provides time-series data points for charting performance trends over time using metricsCollector.getHistoryDataPoints(). Detail the JSON response structure for both endpoints, including fields like totalRequests, successCount, errorCount, averageLatency, p95Latency, and workerStatus. Explain how the dashboard uses these endpoints to visualize system health and performance. Provide examples of how operations teams can monitor system behavior and identify performance issues using these metrics. Include information on the metrics collection mechanism and retention period. Address how these metrics integrate with the overall observability strategy of the system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Queue Connectivity and Backend Issues
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for queue management issues in ContinuityBridge. Explain how the QueueProvider strategy pattern handles different backends (InMemory, RabbitMQ, Kafka) and common connectivity problems with each. Document configuration requirements for RabbitMQ and Kafka, including environment variables like RABBIT_QUEUE_IN, KAFKA_BROKERS, and authentication settings. Address issues with message persistence, delayed message support, and dead-letter queue configuration. Explain the fallback mechanism to InMemory queue when backend initialization fails (server/src/serverQueue.ts). Detail how to diagnose consumer disconnections, message requeuing, and retry exhaustion. Provide troubleshooting steps for each backend, including checking broker availability, network connectivity, and plugin requirements (e.g., rabbitmq_delayed_message_exchange). Include guidance on interpreting queue depth metrics and using the dashboard to monitor queue health.

wiki_catalogs.name: GraphQL Mutations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for ContinuityBridge's GraphQL mutations including processItemIFD, replayEvent, setWorker, and setQueueBackend. For processItemIFD, document the asynchronous processing pattern where XML payloads are enqueued for processing by workers, returning immediately with a traceId. Explain the replayEvent mutation that allows reprocessing of previous events by retrieving the original XML payload and enqueuing it with a new traceId. Document the setWorker mutation that controls worker lifecycle (start/stop) and concurrency configuration. Address common issues like data synchronization delays and rendering performance, providing optimization tips. wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop operations guide for monitoring ContinuityBridge in production. Document the health check endpoint at /api/health defined in render.yaml and its role in service availability monitoring. wiki_catalogs.name: Worker Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed documentation for the worker management endpoints including GET /api/worker/status, POST /api/worker/toggle, POST /api/worker/concurrency, and related queue configuration endpoints. Explain the /api/queue/config endpoint that returns queue backend information and worker configuration. Provide practical examples showing how to programmatically control the worker for maintenance, scaling, and troubleshooting. Document the relationship between worker concurrency and system performance, including recommendations for production settings. Address security considerations for these management endpoints and their role in the overall system operability.

wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Database Connector Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeDatabaseConnector interacts with relational databases (e.g., PostgreSQL via Supabase) to execute queries, insert records, or retrieve data as part of a flow. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how connection details and SQL statements are defined in node configuration. Provide examples showing parameterized queries, transaction handling, and result set processing. Explain error handling for connection failures, query timeouts, and constraint violations. Describe how query results and metadata (e.g., rowCount, querySuccess) are returned in NodeExecutionResult. Address security considerations like SQL injection prevention and credential isolation. Include best practices for optimizing database interactions and monitoring query performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: SFTP Connector Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SFTP Connector Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeSftpConnector transfers files to/from SFTP servers using ssh2 or similar libraries, supporting operations like upload, download, and list. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how connection parameters (host, port, credentials) and file paths are configured in the node. Provide examples showing secure file transfers with private key authentication and handling of file locking or permissions. Explain error handling for network issues, authentication failures, and file conflicts. Describe metadata returned in NodeExecutionResult such as transferSize, transferSuccess, and remotePath. Address security best practices for key management and data encryption. Include guidance on testing connectivity and monitoring transfer reliability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Azure Blob Connector Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Azure Blob Connector Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeAzureBlobConnector interacts with Azure Blob Storage to upload, download, or manage blobs within integration flows. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage access, and detail how connection strings, container names, and blob paths are specified in node configuration. Provide examples showing blob operations with SAS tokens or managed identities, including metadata tagging and conditional requests. Explain error handling for authentication failures, throttling, and network timeouts. Describe how operation results and metadata (e.g., blobSize, etag, uploadSuccess) are returned in NodeExecutionResult. Address security considerations around credential exposure and data encryption. Include best practices for optimizing blob operations and handling large files.

wiki_catalogs.name: SFTP Poller Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SFTP Poller Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeSftpPoller periodically checks an SFTP directory for new files, triggering flow execution when files are detected. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how polling intervals, file filters (regex), and processing strategies (move after read, delete) are configured. Provide examples showing incremental file ingestion and handling of partial uploads. Explain how each detected file initiates a new flow run with file metadata (path, size, timestamp). Describe error handling for connection issues, file locks, and processing failures. Address performance considerations like poll frequency and resource usage. Include best practices for configuring reliable polling and avoiding duplicate processing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Azure Blob Poller Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Azure Blob Poller Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeAzureBlobPoller monitors Azure Blob Storage containers for new or changed blobs, initiating flows upon detection. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage access, and detail how polling frequency, container filters, and blob metadata conditions (e.g., lastModified) are configured. Provide examples showing event-driven processing of uploaded files and integration with Azure Event Grid for push-based notifications. Explain how blob metadata and URLs are passed to downstream nodes. Describe error handling for authentication failures, throttling, and transient network issues. Address cost and performance implications of frequent polling versus event-driven approaches. Include best practices for configuring efficient blob monitoring and ensuring at-least-once delivery semantics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Poller Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Database Poller Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeDatabasePoller periodically queries a database table for new or updated records, triggering flows when changes are detected. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how SQL queries, poll intervals, and watermarking strategies (e.g., lastId, lastTimestamp) are configured. Provide examples showing incremental data extraction from transactional systems and handling of batch processing. Explain how result sets are streamed or paginated and passed to downstream nodes. Describe error handling for connection failures, query timeouts, and schema changes. Address performance considerations like query optimization and index usage. Include best practices for minimizing database load and ensuring reliable change detection.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scheduler Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Scheduler Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeScheduler triggers flow execution based on cron-like schedules or time-based conditions, enabling automated batch processing. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how schedule expressions (e.g., '0 0 * * *') and time zones are defined in node configuration. Provide examples showing daily inventory syncs or hourly report generation. Explain integration with the scheduler-daemon for reliable timing and handling of missed executions. Describe how scheduled triggers are logged and monitored via traceId and execution history. Address time drift, daylight saving transitions, and failure recovery. Include best practices for designing idempotent scheduled flows and avoiding resource contention.

wiki_catalogs.name: HTTP Request Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the HTTP Request Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeHttpRequest sends HTTP requests (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) to external APIs as part of a flow. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how endpoint URLs, headers, authentication (API keys, OAuth), and request bodies are configured in the node. Provide examples showing JSON API interactions, form submissions, and handling of response codes and payloads. Explain error handling for network failures, timeouts, and HTTP error statuses. Describe how response data and metadata (e.g., statusCode, responseTime) are returned in NodeExecutionResult for downstream processing. Address security considerations like TLS configuration and credential protection. Include best practices for retry logic, rate limiting, and API versioning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Email Notification Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Email Notification Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeEmailNotification sends email alerts or reports via SMTP or third-party services (e.g., Resend) during flow execution. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how sender, recipient, subject, and body templates are configured in the node. Provide examples showing plain text and HTML emails with dynamic content from input data. Explain error handling for delivery failures, spam filtering, and invalid addresses. Describe integration with the notifications module and support for attachments or inline images. Address deliverability best practices, DKIM/SPF configuration, and rate limiting. Include guidance on testing email templates and monitoring delivery status.

wiki_catalogs.name: Error Handler Executor
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Error Handler Executor in ContinuityBridge. Explain how executeErrorHandler catches and processes exceptions from upstream nodes, enabling graceful recovery or fallback logic in flows. Document its use of the ExecutionContext for traceId and storage, and detail how error conditions (e.g., errorType, severity) and recovery actions are defined in node configuration. Provide examples showing retry mechanisms, alternative routing, or fallback data insertion. Explain how error context (message, stack trace, input) is preserved and transformed for downstream handling. Describe integration with the error triage system and automatic reporting to /api/error-triage. Address challenges in maintaining flow continuity after errors and preventing infinite retry loops. Include best practices for designing resilient error handling strategies and auditing error resolution.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# ContinuityBridge Project Analysis

## 1. Project Introduction

ContinuityBridge is a middleware proof-of-concept (POC) system designed to process XML IFD payloads from WMS JDA 2018 systems, transform them into canonical JSON format, apply intelligent warehouse routing logic, and dispatch the transformed data to multiple destination systems including SAP, 3PL providers, Mercado Libre, and Amazon.

The core goals of this project are to:
- Provide a flexible middleware solution for enterprise integration scenarios
- Demonstrate XML-to-JSON transformation capabilities with configurable mapping
- Implement intelligent warehouse decisioning based on location, stock levels, SLA, and cost factors
- Support multiple queue backends (InMemory, RabbitMQ, Kafka) with seamless switching
- Offer both REST and GraphQL APIs for system integration

The target audience includes integration engineers, middleware specialists, and enterprise architects who need to connect disparate systems in supply chain and logistics environments.

Sources:
- [README.md](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\README.md)

## 2. Technical Architecture

The ContinuityBridge architecture follows a modular, layered approach with clear separation of concerns between components. The system processes data through a well-defined pipeline that transforms incoming XML payloads into canonical JSON, makes intelligent routing decisions, and dispatches to multiple endpoints.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[XML IFD Payload] --> B[Queue]
    B --> C[Worker Process]
    C --> D[Pipeline Processing]
    D --> E[XML to Canonical]
    D --> F[Warehouse Decision]
    D --> G[Fan-Out Dispatch]
    D --> H[Metrics Collection]
    E --> I[Canonical JSON]
    F --> J[Warehouse Selection]
    G --> K[SAP]
    G --> L[3PL]
    G --> M[Mercado Libre]
    G --> N[Amazon]
    H --> O[Real-time Metrics]
```

The architecture is built around several key design patterns:
- **Strategy Pattern**: For queue backend implementation (InMemory, RabbitMQ, Kafka)
- **Pipeline Pattern**: For processing XML payloads through multiple stages
- **Dependency Injection**: For injecting services into resolvers and components
- **Event Sourcing**: For tracking processing events and decisions

The system uses a dual-API approach with both REST and GraphQL endpoints, providing flexibility for different integration scenarios. The worker process consumes messages from the configured queue backend and processes them through the pipeline, with results dispatched to multiple receivers simultaneously.

Sources:
- [README.md](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\README.md)
- [package.json](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\package.json)

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **Server**: `server/index.ts` - Main server entry point that initializes Express, middleware, and routes
- **Client**: `client/src/main.tsx` - React application entry point that renders the dashboard

### Core Modules
- **Pipeline**: `server/src/core/pipeline.ts` - Orchestrates the complete processing flow from XML input to final dispatch
- **XML Transformer**: `server/src/transform/xml-to-canonical.ts` - Converts XML IFD payloads to canonical JSON format
- **Origin Decider**: `server/src/decision/origin-decider.ts` - Implements warehouse selection logic based on multiple factors
- **Queue Providers**: `server/src/queue/` - Strategy pattern implementation for different queue backends
- **Worker**: `server/src/workers/worker.ts` - Processes messages from the queue with configurable concurrency

### Configuration Approach
- Environment variables control key aspects like queue backend selection and worker concurrency
- YAML-based mapping configuration (`mapping.yml`) defines XML-to-JSON transformation rules
- Queue backend selection via `QUEUE_BACKEND` environment variable with fallback to InMemory
- Centralized configuration management in `server/src/core/env-validator.ts`

### External Dependencies
- **fast-xml-parser**: For XML parsing and transformation
- **js-yaml**: For loading YAML mapping configurations
- **amqplib**: For RabbitMQ integration
- **kafkajs**: For Kafka integration
- **Apollo Server**: For GraphQL API implementation
- **Express**: For REST API implementation

### Integration Points
- **Queue Interfaces**: Configurable queue backends (InMemory, RabbitMQ, Kafka)
- **External Systems**: Simulated integrations with SAP, 3PL, Mercado Libre, and Amazon
- **API Endpoints**: REST and GraphQL interfaces for system interaction
- **Dashboard**: React-based monitoring interface with real-time metrics

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Client Dashboard] --> B[REST API]
    A --> C[GraphQL API]
    B --> D[Pipeline]
    C --> D
    D --> E[XML Transformer]
    D --> F[Origin Decider]
    D --> G[Queue Provider]
    G --> H[InMemory]
    G --> I[RabbitMQ]
    G --> J[Kafka]
    D --> K[Dispatch Service]
    K --> L[SAP]
    K --> M[3PL]
    K --> N[Mercado Libre]
    K --> O[Amazon]
```

Sources:
- [server/index.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\index.ts)
- [client/src/main.tsx](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\client\src\main.tsx)
- [server/src/core/pipeline.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\core\pipeline.ts)
- [server/src/transform/xml-to-canonical.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\transform\xml-to-canonical.ts)
- [server/src/decision/origin-decider.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\decision\origin-decider.ts)
- [server/src/queue/QueueProvider.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\queue\QueueProvider.ts)
- [server/src/workers/worker.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\workers\worker.ts)

## 4. Key Features

### XML Transformation
The system converts XML IFD payloads to canonical JSON format using configurable YAML mappings. The transformation process validates the XML structure and applies field-level mappings to produce standardized output.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Processing: Receive XML
    Processing --> Validating: Parse XML
    Validating --> Transforming: Apply Mappings
    Transforming --> Decisioning: Generate Canonical JSON
    Decisioning --> Dispatching: Warehouse Selection
    Dispatching --> Completed: Send to Destinations
    Completed --> Idle: Update Metrics
    Processing --> Error: Invalid XML
    Error --> Idle: Log Error
```

### Intelligent Warehouse Routing
The origin decider evaluates multiple factors including distance, stock availability, SLA, and cost to select the optimal warehouse for order fulfillment. The decisioning algorithm uses a weighted scoring system to rank available warehouses.

### Swappable Queue Backends
The system supports three queue implementations through a strategy pattern:
- InMemoryQueue: For development and testing
- RabbitQueue: For production with RabbitMQ/LavinMQ
- KafkaQueue: For high-volume scenarios with Kafka

### Fan-Out Dispatch
The system simultaneously dispatches processed payloads to multiple destination systems (SAP, 3PL, Mercado Libre, Amazon) using a fan-out pattern. Each dispatch is handled independently to prevent one failed integration from blocking others.

### Real-Time Monitoring
The React-based dashboard provides real-time visibility into system performance with metrics for latency, throughput, queue depth, and error rates. The dual API approach allows both REST and GraphQL access to monitoring data.

Sources:
- [README.md](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\README.md)
- [server/src/core/pipeline.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\core\pipeline.ts)
- [server/src/transform/xml-to-canonical.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\transform\xml-to-canonical.ts)
- [server/src/decision/origin-decider.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\decision\origin-decider.ts)
- [server/src/queue/](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\queue)
- [server/src/receivers/dispatch.ts](c:\ReactProjects\ContinuityBridge\server\src\receivers\dispatch.ts)
</blog>
